<tei-text data-xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="base" id="base" data-origname="text"><tei-body data-origname="body"><tei-div type="leaf" n="9" data-origname="div"><tei-pb facs="#f008" data-origname="pb" data-empty=""></tei-pb>

                <tei-p data-origname="p">altogether tell. Certain it is, however, that<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> this great power of blackness
                    in him derives<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> its force from its appeals to that Calvinistic<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> sense
                    of <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Innate</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Depravity</tei-hi> and
                    original Sin, from whose<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> visitations, in some shape or other, no deeply
                    thinking<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> mind is always & wholly free. <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">For, in</tei-hi> certain
                    moods,<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> no man can weigh this world, without throwing<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> in something, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">somehow</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Original</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Sin</tei-hi>, to strike the<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    uneven balance. At all events, perhaps no<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">writer</tei-hi> has ever <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">wielded</tei-hi> this
                    terrific thought with<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>greater <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">terror</tei-hi> than this same harmless<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> Hawthorne. Still more:
                    this black <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">conceit
                    pervades him,</tei-hi>
               <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> through & through. You may be witched by his<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    sunlight,-- transported by the bright gildings<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> in the skies he builds over
                    you;-- but there is<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> the blackness of darkness beyond; and even <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">his</tei-hi>
               <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">bright</tei-hi> gildings but
                    fringe, and play upon the<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> edges of thunder-clouds<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">.</tei-hi>-- In one word,
                    the<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> world is mistaken in this Nathaniel Hawthorne.<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> He himself must
                    often have smiled at its<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> absurd misconception <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">of him.</tei-hi> He is
                    immeasurably deeper<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> than the plummet of the mere critic. For it<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> is
                    not the <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">brain</tei-hi> that
                    can test such a man;<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> it is only the heart. You cannot come to<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> know
                    greatness by <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">inspecting
                    it;</tei-hi> there is no<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> glimpse to be caught of it, except by intuition;<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    you <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">need not</tei-hi> ring
                    it, you but touch it, and you find<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> it is gold</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p"> now <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">it is</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">that</tei-hi> blackness in
                    Hawthorne, of<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> which I have spoken, that so fixes & fascinates<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    me. It may be<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">nevertheless,</tei-hi> that
                    it is too</tei-p>
            </tei-div>

                <tei-p data-origname="p">
                    </tei-p></tei-div></tei-body></tei-text>

                    moods,<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> no man can weigh this world, without throwing<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> in something, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">somehow</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Original</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Sin</tei-hi>, to strike the<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    uneven balance. At all events, perhaps no<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">writer</tei-hi> has ever <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">wielded</tei-hi> this
                    terrific thought with<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>greater <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">terror</tei-hi> than this same harmless<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> Hawthorne. Still more:
                    this black <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">conceit
                    pervades him,</tei-hi>
               <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> through & through. You may be witched by his<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    sunlight,-- transported by the bright gildings<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> in the skies he builds over
                    you;-- but there is<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> the blackness of darkness beyond; and even <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">his</tei-hi>
               <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">bright</tei-hi> gildings but
                    fringe, and play upon the<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> edges of thunder-clouds<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">.</tei-hi>-- In one word,
                    the<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> world is mistaken in this Nathaniel Hawthorne.<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> He himself must
                    often have smiled at its<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> absurd misconception <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">of him.</tei-hi> He is
                    immeasurably deeper<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> than the plummet of the mere critic. For it<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> is
                    not the <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">brain</tei-hi> that
                    can test such a man;<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> it is only the heart. You cannot come to<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> know
                    greatness by <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">inspecting
                    it;</tei-hi> there is no<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> glimpse to be caught of it, except by intuition;<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    you <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">need not</tei-hi> ring
                    it, you but touch it, and you find<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> it is gold</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p"> now <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">it is</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">that</tei-hi> blackness in
                    Hawthorne, of<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> which I have spoken, that so fixes & fascinates<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    me. It may be<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">nevertheless,</tei-hi> that
                    it is too</tei-p>

                    </tei-p></tei-div></tei-body></tei-text>

                    sunlight,-- transported by the bright gildings<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> in the skies he builds over
                    you;-- but there is<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> the blackness of darkness beyond; and even <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">his</tei-hi>
               <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>

                    fringe, and play upon the<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> edges of thunder-clouds<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">.</tei-hi>-- In one word,

                    greatness by <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">inspecting
                    it;</tei-hi> there is no<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> glimpse to be caught of it, except by intuition;<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    you <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">need not</tei-hi> ring
                    it, you but touch it, and you find<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> it is gold</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p"> now <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">it is</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">that</tei-hi> blackness in
                    Hawthorne, of<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> which I have spoken, that so fixes & fascinates<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    me. It may be<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">nevertheless,</tei-hi> that

<tei-text data-xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="base" id="base" data-origname="text"><tei-body data-origname="body"><tei-div type="leaf" n="9" data-origname="div"><tei-pb facs="#f008" data-origname="pb" data-empty=""></tei-pb>

                <tei-p data-origname="p">altogether tell. Certain it is, however, that<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> this great power of blackness
                    in him derives<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> its force from its appeals to that Calvinistic<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> sense
                    of <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Innate</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Depravity</tei-hi> and
                    original Sin, from whose<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> visitations, in some shape or other, no deeply
                    thinking<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> mind is always & wholly free. <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">For, in</tei-hi> certain
                    moods,<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> no man can weigh this world, without throwing<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> in something, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">somehow</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Original</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Sin</tei-hi>, to strike the<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    uneven balance. At all events, perhaps no<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">writer</tei-hi> has ever <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">wielded</tei-hi> this
                    terrific thought with<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>greater <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">terror</tei-hi> than this same harmless<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> Hawthorne. Still more:
                    this black <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">conceit
                    pervades him,</tei-hi>
               <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> through & through. You may be witched by his<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    sunlight,-- transported by the bright gildings<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> in the skies he builds over
                    you;-- but there is<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> the blackness of darkness beyond; and even <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">his</tei-hi>
               <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">bright</tei-hi> gildings but
                    fringe, and play upon the<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> edges of thunder-clouds<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">.</tei-hi>-- In one word,
                    the<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> world is mistaken in this Nathaniel Hawthorne.<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> He himself must
                    often have smiled at its<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> absurd misconception <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">of him.</tei-hi> He is
                    immeasurably deeper<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> than the plummet of the mere critic. For it<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> is
                    not the <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">brain</tei-hi> that
                    can test such a man;<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> it is only the heart. You cannot come to<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> know
                    greatness by <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">inspecting
                    it;</tei-hi> there is no<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> glimpse to be caught of it, except by intuition;<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    you <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">need not</tei-hi> ring
                    it, you but touch it, and you find<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> it is gold</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p"> now <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">it is</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">that</tei-hi> blackness in
                    Hawthorne, of<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> which I have spoken, that so fixes & fascinates<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    me. It may be<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">nevertheless,</tei-hi> that
                    it is too</tei-p>
            </tei-div>

                <tei-p data-origname="p">
                    </tei-p></tei-div></tei-body></tei-text>

               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Sin</tei-hi>, to strike the<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    uneven balance. At all events, perhaps no<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">writer</tei-hi> has ever <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">wielded</tei-hi> this
                    terrific thought with<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>greater <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">terror</tei-hi> than this same harmless<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> Hawthorne. Still more:
                    this black <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">conceit
                    pervades him,</tei-hi>
               <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> through & through. You may be witched by his<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    sunlight,-- transported by the bright gildings<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> in the skies he builds over
                    you;-- but there is<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> the blackness of darkness beyond; and even <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">his</tei-hi>
               <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">bright</tei-hi> gildings but
                    fringe, and play upon the<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> edges of thunder-clouds<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">.</tei-hi>-- In one word,
                    the<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> world is mistaken in this Nathaniel Hawthorne.<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> He himself must
                    often have smiled at its<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> absurd misconception <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">of him.</tei-hi> He is
                    immeasurably deeper<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> than the plummet of the mere critic. For it<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> is
                    not the <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">brain</tei-hi> that
                    can test such a man;<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> it is only the heart. You cannot come to<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> know
                    greatness by <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">inspecting
                    it;</tei-hi> there is no<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> glimpse to be caught of it, except by intuition;<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    you <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">need not</tei-hi> ring
                    it, you but touch it, and you find<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> it is gold</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p"> now <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">it is</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">that</tei-hi> blackness in
                    Hawthorne, of<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> which I have spoken, that so fixes & fascinates<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    me. It may be<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">nevertheless,</tei-hi> that
                    it is too</tei-p>

                <tei-p data-origname="p">altogether tell. Certain it is, however, that<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> this great power of blackness
                    in him derives<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> its force from its appeals to that Calvinistic<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> sense

                    original Sin, from whose<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> visitations, in some shape or other, no deeply
                    thinking<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> mind is always & wholly free. <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">For, in</tei-hi> certain
                    moods,<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> no man can weigh this world, without throwing<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> in something, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">somehow</tei-hi>

                    uneven balance. At all events, perhaps no<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>

                    terrific thought with<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>greater <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">terror</tei-hi> than this same harmless<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> Hawthorne. Still more:
                    this black <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">conceit
                    pervades him,</tei-hi>

                    sunlight,-- transported by the bright gildings<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> in the skies he builds over
                    you;-- but there is<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> the blackness of darkness beyond; and even <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">his</tei-hi>
               <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">bright</tei-hi> gildings but
                    fringe, and play upon the<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> edges of thunder-clouds<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">.</tei-hi>-- In one word,
                    the<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> world is mistaken in this Nathaniel Hawthorne.<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> He himself must
                    often have smiled at its<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> absurd misconception <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">of him.</tei-hi> He is

                    it, you but touch it, and you find<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> it is gold</tei-p>

                    you <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">need not</tei-hi> ring
                    it, you but touch it, and you find<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> it is gold</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p"> now <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">it is</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">that</tei-hi> blackness in
                    Hawthorne, of<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> which I have spoken, that so fixes & fascinates<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    me. It may be<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">nevertheless,</tei-hi> that
                    it is too</tei-p>

                    </tei-p></tei-div></tei-body></tei-text>

<tei-text data-xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="base" id="base" data-origname="text"><tei-body data-origname="body"><tei-div type="leaf" n="9" data-origname="div"><tei-pb facs="#f008" data-origname="pb" data-empty=""></tei-pb>

                <tei-p data-origname="p">altogether tell. Certain it is, however, that<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> this great power of blackness
                    in him derives<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> its force from its appeals to that Calvinistic<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> sense
                    of <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Innate</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Depravity</tei-hi> and
                    original Sin, from whose<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> visitations, in some shape or other, no deeply
                    thinking<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> mind is always & wholly free. <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">For, in</tei-hi> certain
                    moods,<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> no man can weigh this world, without throwing<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> in something, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">somehow</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Original</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Sin</tei-hi>, to strike the<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    uneven balance. At all events, perhaps no<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">writer</tei-hi> has ever <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">wielded</tei-hi> this
                    terrific thought with<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>greater <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">terror</tei-hi> than this same harmless<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> Hawthorne. Still more:
                    this black <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">conceit
                    pervades him,</tei-hi>
               <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> through & through. You may be witched by his<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    sunlight,-- transported by the bright gildings<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> in the skies he builds over
                    you;-- but there is<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> the blackness of darkness beyond; and even <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">his</tei-hi>
               <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">bright</tei-hi> gildings but
                    fringe, and play upon the<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> edges of thunder-clouds<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">.</tei-hi>-- In one word,
                    the<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> world is mistaken in this Nathaniel Hawthorne.<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> He himself must
                    often have smiled at its<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> absurd misconception <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">of him.</tei-hi> He is
                    immeasurably deeper<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> than the plummet of the mere critic. For it<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> is
                    not the <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">brain</tei-hi> that
                    can test such a man;<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> it is only the heart. You cannot come to<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> know
                    greatness by <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">inspecting
                    it;</tei-hi> there is no<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> glimpse to be caught of it, except by intuition;<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    you <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">need not</tei-hi> ring
                    it, you but touch it, and you find<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> it is gold</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p"> now <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">it is</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">that</tei-hi> blackness in
                    Hawthorne, of<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> which I have spoken, that so fixes & fascinates<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    me. It may be<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">nevertheless,</tei-hi> that
                    it is too</tei-p>
            </tei-div>

                <tei-p data-origname="p">
                    </tei-p></tei-div></tei-body></tei-text>

               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Sin</tei-hi>, to strike the<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    uneven balance. At all events, perhaps no<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">writer</tei-hi> has ever <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">wielded</tei-hi> this
                    terrific thought with<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>greater <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">terror</tei-hi> than this same harmless<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> Hawthorne. Still more:
                    this black <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">conceit
                    pervades him,</tei-hi>
               <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> through & through. You may be witched by his<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    sunlight,-- transported by the bright gildings<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> in the skies he builds over
                    you;-- but there is<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> the blackness of darkness beyond; and even <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">his</tei-hi>
               <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">bright</tei-hi> gildings but
                    fringe, and play upon the<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> edges of thunder-clouds<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">.</tei-hi>-- In one word,
                    the<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> world is mistaken in this Nathaniel Hawthorne.<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> He himself must
                    often have smiled at its<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> absurd misconception <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">of him.</tei-hi> He is
                    immeasurably deeper<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> than the plummet of the mere critic. For it<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> is
                    not the <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">brain</tei-hi> that
                    can test such a man;<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> it is only the heart. You cannot come to<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> know
                    greatness by <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">inspecting
                    it;</tei-hi> there is no<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> glimpse to be caught of it, except by intuition;<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    you <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">need not</tei-hi> ring
                    it, you but touch it, and you find<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> it is gold</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p"> now <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">it is</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">that</tei-hi> blackness in
                    Hawthorne, of<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> which I have spoken, that so fixes & fascinates<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    me. It may be<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">nevertheless,</tei-hi> that
                    it is too</tei-p>
            </tei-div>

            <tei-div type="leaf" n="10" data-origname="div">
                <tei-p data-origname="p">
                    </tei-p></tei-div></tei-body></tei-text>

<tei-text data-xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="base" id="base" data-origname="text"><tei-body data-origname="body"><tei-div type="leaf" n="9" data-origname="div"><tei-pb facs="#f008" data-origname="pb" data-empty=""></tei-pb>

                <tei-p data-origname="p">altogether tell. Certain it is, however, that<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> this great power of blackness
                    in him derives<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> its force from its appeals to that Calvinistic<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> sense
                    of <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Innate</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Depravity</tei-hi> and
                    original Sin, from whose<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> visitations, in some shape or other, no deeply
                    thinking<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> mind is always & wholly free. <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">For, in</tei-hi> certain
                    moods,<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> no man can weigh this world, without throwing<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> in something, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">somehow</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Original</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Sin</tei-hi>, to strike the<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    uneven balance. At all events, perhaps no<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">writer</tei-hi> has ever <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">wielded</tei-hi> this
                    terrific thought with<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>greater <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">terror</tei-hi> than this same harmless<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> Hawthorne. Still more:
                    this black <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">conceit
                    pervades him,</tei-hi>
               <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> through & through. You may be witched by his<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    sunlight,-- transported by the bright gildings<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> in the skies he builds over
                    you;-- but there is<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> the blackness of darkness beyond; and even <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">his</tei-hi>
               <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">bright</tei-hi> gildings but
                    fringe, and play upon the<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> edges of thunder-clouds<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">.</tei-hi>-- In one word,
                    the<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> world is mistaken in this Nathaniel Hawthorne.<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> He himself must
                    often have smiled at its<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> absurd misconception <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">of him.</tei-hi> He is
                    immeasurably deeper<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> than the plummet of the mere critic. For it<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> is
                    not the <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">brain</tei-hi> that
                    can test such a man;<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> it is only the heart. You cannot come to<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> know
                    greatness by <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">inspecting
                    it;</tei-hi> there is no<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> glimpse to be caught of it, except by intuition;<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    you <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">need not</tei-hi> ring
                    it, you but touch it, and you find<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> it is gold</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p"> now <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">it is</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">that</tei-hi> blackness in
                    Hawthorne, of<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> which I have spoken, that so fixes & fascinates<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    me. It may be<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">nevertheless,</tei-hi> that
                    it is too</tei-p>
            </tei-div>

            <tei-div type="leaf" n="10" data-origname="div">
                <tei-p data-origname="p">
                    </tei-p></tei-div></tei-body></tei-text>

<tei-text data-xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="base" id="base" data-origname="text"><tei-body data-origname="body"><tei-div type="leaf" n="9" data-origname="div"><tei-pb facs="#f008" data-origname="pb" data-empty=""></tei-pb>

                <tei-p data-origname="p">altogether tell. Certain it is, however, that<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> this great power of blackness
                    in him derives<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> its force from its appeals to that Calvinistic<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> sense
                    of <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Innate</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Depravity</tei-hi> and
                    original Sin, from whose<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> visitations, in some shape or other, no deeply
                    thinking<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> mind is always & wholly free. <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">For, in</tei-hi> certain
                    moods,<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> no man can weigh this world, without throwing<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> in something, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">somehow</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Original</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Sin</tei-hi>, to strike the<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    uneven balance. At all events, perhaps no<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">writer</tei-hi> has ever <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">wielded</tei-hi> this
                    terrific thought with<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>greater <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">terror</tei-hi> than this same harmless<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> Hawthorne. Still more:
                    this black <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">conceit
                    pervades him,</tei-hi>
               <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> through & through. You may be witched by his<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    sunlight,-- transported by the bright gildings<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> in the skies he builds over
                    you;-- but there is<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> the blackness of darkness beyond; and even <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">his</tei-hi>
               <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">bright</tei-hi> gildings but
                    fringe, and play upon the<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> edges of thunder-clouds<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">.</tei-hi>-- In one word,
                    the<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> world is mistaken in this Nathaniel Hawthorne.<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> He himself must
                    often have smiled at its<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> absurd misconception <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">of him.</tei-hi> He is
                    immeasurably deeper<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> than the plummet of the mere critic. For it<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> is
                    not the <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">brain</tei-hi> that
                    can test such a man;<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> it is only the heart. You cannot come to<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> know
                    greatness by <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">inspecting
                    it;</tei-hi> there is no<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> glimpse to be caught of it, except by intuition;<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    you <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">need not</tei-hi> ring
                    it, you but touch it, and you find<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> it is gold</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p"> now <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">it is</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">that</tei-hi> blackness in
                    Hawthorne, of<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> which I have spoken, that so fixes & fascinates<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    me. It may be<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">nevertheless,</tei-hi> that
                    it is too</tei-p>
            </tei-div>

            <tei-div type="leaf" n="10" data-origname="div">
                <tei-p data-origname="p">
                    </tei-p></tei-div></tei-body></tei-text>

<tei-text data-xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="base" id="base" data-origname="text"><tei-body data-origname="body"><tei-div type="leaf" n="10" data-origname="div"><tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-pb facs="#f009" data-origname="pb" data-empty=""></tei-pb>
                </tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">largely developed in him. Perhaps he does<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>not give us a ray of his light for
                    every shade <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>of his <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    dark.</tei-hi> But however this may be, this <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>blackness it is that furnishes
                    the infinite obscure <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>of his back-ground,-- that back-ground, against<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    which Shakespeare plays his grandest conceits, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>the things that have made
                    for Shakespeare <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>his <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">loftiest, but most circumscribed</tei-hi> renown, as the <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">profoundest</tei-hi>
               <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>of
                    thinkers. For by philosophers Shakespeare is <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>not <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">adored</tei-hi> as the great
                    man of tragedy and <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>comedy.--"Off with his head! so much for <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>Buckingham!"
                    this sort of rant, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    interlined</tei-hi>
               <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> by <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    an</tei-hi>other hand, bring<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    s</tei-hi> down the house,--those <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>mistaken souls, who dream of Shakespeare <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>as
                    a <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">mere</tei-hi> man of
                    Richard-the-Third humps, and <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>Macbeth daggers. But it is those deep <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">far-away</tei-hi> things in
                    him; those occasional flashings-forth of <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>the intuitive Truth in him; those
                    short, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>quick probings <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">at</tei-hi> the very axis of reality:-- these <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>are the things
                    that make Shakespeare, Shakes-<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>peare. Through the <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">mouths</tei-hi> of the dark
                    charac-<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>ters of Hamlet, Timon, Lear, and Iago, he <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>craftily says, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">or </tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">sometimes</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi"> insinuates</tei-hi> the
                    things, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">which</tei-hi> we
                    feel to be so <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>terrifically true, that it were all but mad-<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>ness for
                    any good man, in his own proper<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>character, to utter, or even hint of them. <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Tormented</tei-hi> into
                    desperation, Lear the frantic King <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">tears off the mask,</tei-hi>
               <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">&</tei-hi> speaks the

<tei-text data-xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="base" id="base" data-origname="text"><tei-body data-origname="body"><tei-div type="leaf" n="10" data-origname="div"><tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-pb facs="#f009" data-origname="pb" data-empty=""></tei-pb>
                </tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">largely developed in him. Perhaps he does<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>not give us a ray of his light for
                    every shade <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>of his <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    dark.</tei-hi> But however this may be, this <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>blackness it is that furnishes
                    the infinite obscure <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>of his back-ground,-- that back-ground, against<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    which Shakespeare plays his grandest conceits, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>the things that have made
                    for Shakespeare <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>his <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">loftiest, but most circumscribed</tei-hi> renown, as the <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">profoundest</tei-hi>
               <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>of
                    thinkers. For by philosophers Shakespeare is <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>not <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">adored</tei-hi> as the great
                    man of tragedy and <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>comedy.--"Off with his head! so much for <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>Buckingham!"
                    this sort of rant, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    interlined</tei-hi>
               <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> by <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    an</tei-hi>other hand, bring<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    s</tei-hi> down the house,--those <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>mistaken souls, who dream of Shakespeare <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>as
                    a <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">mere</tei-hi> man of
                    Richard-the-Third humps, and <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>Macbeth daggers. But it is those deep <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">far-away</tei-hi> things in
                    him; those occasional flashings-forth of <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>the intuitive Truth in him; those
                    short, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>quick probings <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">at</tei-hi> the very axis of reality:-- these <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>are the things
                    that make Shakespeare, Shakes-<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>peare. Through the <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">mouths</tei-hi> of the dark
                    charac-<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>ters of Hamlet, Timon, Lear, and Iago, he <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>craftily says, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">or </tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">sometimes</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi"> insinuates</tei-hi> the
                    things, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">which</tei-hi> we
                    feel to be so <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>terrifically true, that it were all but mad-<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>ness for
                    any good man, in his own proper<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>character, to utter, or even hint of them. <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Tormented</tei-hi> into
                    desperation, Lear the frantic King <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">tears off the mask,</tei-hi>
               <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">&</tei-hi> speaks the
                    sane madness of vital truth. <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>But, as I before said, it is the least part
                    of <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>genius that attracts admiration. And so, </tei-p>
            </tei-div>

                </tei-div></tei-body></tei-text>

                    things, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">which</tei-hi> we
                    feel to be so <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>terrifically true, that it were all but mad-<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>ness for
                    any good man, in his own proper<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>character, to utter, or even hint of them. <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Tormented</tei-hi> into
                    desperation, Lear the frantic King <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">tears off the mask,</tei-hi>
               <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">&</tei-hi> speaks the
                    sane madness of vital truth. <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>But, as I before said, it is the least part
                    of <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>genius that attracts admiration. And so, </tei-p>

<tei-text data-xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="base" id="base" data-origname="text"><tei-body data-origname="body"><tei-div type="leaf" n="10" data-origname="div"><tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-pb facs="#f009" data-origname="pb" data-empty=""></tei-pb>
                </tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">largely developed in him. Perhaps he does<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>not give us a ray of his light for
                    every shade <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>of his <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    dark.</tei-hi> But however this may be, this <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>blackness it is that furnishes
                    the infinite obscure <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>of his back-ground,-- that back-ground, against<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    which Shakespeare plays his grandest conceits, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>the things that have made
                    for Shakespeare <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>his <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">loftiest, but most circumscribed</tei-hi> renown, as the <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">profoundest</tei-hi>
               <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>of
                    thinkers. For by philosophers Shakespeare is <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>not <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">adored</tei-hi> as the great
                    man of tragedy and <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>comedy.--"Off with his head! so much for <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>Buckingham!"
                    this sort of rant, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    interlined</tei-hi>
               <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> by <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    an</tei-hi>other hand, bring<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    s</tei-hi> down the house,--those <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>mistaken souls, who dream of Shakespeare <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>as
                    a <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">mere</tei-hi> man of
                    Richard-the-Third humps, and <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>Macbeth daggers. But it is those deep <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">far-away</tei-hi> things in
                    him; those occasional flashings-forth of <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>the intuitive Truth in him; those
                    short, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>quick probings <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">at</tei-hi> the very axis of reality:-- these <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>are the things
                    that make Shakespeare, Shakes-<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>peare. Through the <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">mouths</tei-hi> of the dark
                    charac-<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>ters of Hamlet, Timon, Lear, and Iago, he <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>craftily says, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">or </tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">sometimes</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi"> insinuates</tei-hi> the
                    things, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">which</tei-hi> we
                    feel to be so <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>terrifically true, that it were all but mad-<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>ness for
                    any good man, in his own proper<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>character, to utter, or even hint of them. <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Tormented</tei-hi> into
                    desperation, Lear the frantic King <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">tears off the mask,</tei-hi>
               <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">&</tei-hi> speaks the
                    sane madness of vital truth. <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>But, as I before said, it is the least part
                    of <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>genius that attracts admiration. And so, </tei-p>
            </tei-div>

                    short, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>quick probings <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">at</tei-hi> the very axis of reality:-- these <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>are the things
                    that make Shakespeare, Shakes-<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>peare. Through the <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">mouths</tei-hi> of the dark
                    charac-<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>ters of Hamlet, Timon, Lear, and Iago, he <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>craftily says, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">or </tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">sometimes</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi"> insinuates</tei-hi> the
                    things, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">which</tei-hi> we
                    feel to be so <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>terrifically true, that it were all but mad-<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>ness for
                    any good man, in his own proper<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>character, to utter, or even hint of them. <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Tormented</tei-hi> into
                    desperation, Lear the frantic King <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">tears off the mask,</tei-hi>
               <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">&</tei-hi> speaks the
                    sane madness of vital truth. <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>But, as I before said, it is the least part
                    of <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>genius that attracts admiration. And so, </tei-p>

<tei-text data-xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="base" id="base" data-origname="text"><tei-body data-origname="body"><tei-div type="leaf" n="10" data-origname="div"><tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-pb facs="#f009" data-origname="pb" data-empty=""></tei-pb>
                </tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">largely developed in him. Perhaps he does<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>not give us a ray of his light for
                    every shade <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>of his <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    dark.</tei-hi> But however this may be, this <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>blackness it is that furnishes
                    the infinite obscure <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>of his back-ground,-- that back-ground, against<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    which Shakespeare plays his grandest conceits, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>the things that have made
                    for Shakespeare <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>his <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">loftiest, but most circumscribed</tei-hi> renown, as the <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">profoundest</tei-hi>
               <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>of
                    thinkers. For by philosophers Shakespeare is <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>not <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">adored</tei-hi> as the great
                    man of tragedy and <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>comedy.--"Off with his head! so much for <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>Buckingham!"
                    this sort of rant, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    interlined</tei-hi>
               <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> by <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    an</tei-hi>other hand, bring<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    s</tei-hi> down the house,--those <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>mistaken souls, who dream of Shakespeare <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>as
                    a <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">mere</tei-hi> man of
                    Richard-the-Third humps, and <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>Macbeth daggers. But it is those deep <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">far-away</tei-hi> things in
                    him; those occasional flashings-forth of <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>the intuitive Truth in him; those
                    short, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>quick probings <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">at</tei-hi> the very axis of reality:-- these <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>are the things
                    that make Shakespeare, Shakes-<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>peare. Through the <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">mouths</tei-hi> of the dark
                    charac-<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>ters of Hamlet, Timon, Lear, and Iago, he <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>craftily says, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">or </tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">sometimes</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi"> insinuates</tei-hi> the
                    things, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">which</tei-hi> we
                    feel to be so <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>terrifically true, that it were all but mad-<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>ness for
                    any good man, in his own proper<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>character, to utter, or even hint of them. <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Tormented</tei-hi> into
                    desperation, Lear the frantic King <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">tears off the mask,</tei-hi>
               <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">&</tei-hi> speaks the
                    sane madness of vital truth. <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>But, as I before said, it is the least part
                    of <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>genius that attracts admiration. And so, </tei-p>
            </tei-div>

               <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> by <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    an</tei-hi>other hand, bring<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    s</tei-hi> down the house,--those <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>mistaken souls, who dream of Shakespeare <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>as
                    a <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">mere</tei-hi> man of
                    Richard-the-Third humps, and <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>Macbeth daggers. But it is those deep <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">far-away</tei-hi> things in
                    him; those occasional flashings-forth of <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>the intuitive Truth in him; those
                    short, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>quick probings <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">at</tei-hi> the very axis of reality:-- these <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>are the things
                    that make Shakespeare, Shakes-<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>peare. Through the <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">mouths</tei-hi> of the dark
                    charac-<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>ters of Hamlet, Timon, Lear, and Iago, he <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>craftily says, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">or </tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">sometimes</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi"> insinuates</tei-hi> the
                    things, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">which</tei-hi> we
                    feel to be so <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>terrifically true, that it were all but mad-<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>ness for
                    any good man, in his own proper<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>character, to utter, or even hint of them. <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Tormented</tei-hi> into
                    desperation, Lear the frantic King <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">tears off the mask,</tei-hi>
               <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">&</tei-hi> speaks the
                    sane madness of vital truth. <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>But, as I before said, it is the least part
                    of <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>genius that attracts admiration. And so, </tei-p>
            </tei-div>
