                    Truth<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,--</tei-hi>even though <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    it be covertly, and by snatches.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p"> But <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">if</tei-hi> this view of
                    the all-popular <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> Shakspeare <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">be</tei-hi> seldom taken by his readers, and if very <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> few who
                    extol him, have ever read him deeply,<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">or, perhaps,</tei-hi> only
                    have seen him on the tricky stage<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">, (</tei-hi>which <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> alone made, and is still making him his
                    mere <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> mob renown<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">)
                    --</tei-hi> if few men have time, or patience, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> or palate <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi" data-empty=""></tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi> for the spiritual
                    truth as it is in <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    that</tei-hi> great genius; -- it is<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    then,</tei-hi> no matter of surprise <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> that <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">in a contemporaneous age</tei-hi>,
                    Nathaniel Hawthorne is a man, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">as yet, almost</tei-hi> utterly <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>mistaken among men. Here &
                    there, in some <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>quiet arm-chair in the noisy town, or some <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>deep nook
                    among the <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">noisless</tei-hi>
                    mountains, he may <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>be appreciated for something of what he is.</tei-p>
            </tei-div>

            <tei-div type="leaf" n="12" data-origname="div">
                </tei-div></tei-body></tei-text>

<tei-text data-xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="base" id="base" data-origname="text"><tei-body data-origname="body"><tei-div type="leaf" n="11" data-origname="div"><tei-pb facs="#f010" data-origname="pb" data-empty=""></tei-pb>

                <tei-p data-origname="p">
                    <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">much of the blind,
                    unbridled</tei-hi> admiration that has been heaped <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>upon Shakespeare, has been
                    lavished upon the <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> least part of him. And few of his endless <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    commentators & critics seem to have <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">remembered,</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">or even</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi>
               <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>that the
                    immediate products of a great mind <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> are not so great, as that undeveloped, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">(& sometimes
                    undevelopable)</tei-hi> yet <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> dimly-discern<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">able</tei-hi> greatness, to
                    which <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">these
                    immediate products</tei-hi> are but the infallible indices. In Shakespeare's <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    tomb lies infinitely more than <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Shakspeare</tei-hi> ever wrote. <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> And if I magnify Shakespeare,
                    it is not so much <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> for what he did<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">do,</tei-hi> as for what he
                    did not <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> do<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">or refrained from doing.</tei-hi>
                    For in this world of lies, Truth is <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">forced</tei-hi> to <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> fly like a scared white doe in the
                    woodlands; <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> and only by cunning glimpses will she reveal <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> herself,
                    as in Shakespeare and other <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">masters</tei-hi> of <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> the great <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Art</tei-hi> of Telling the
                    Truth<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,--</tei-hi>even though <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    it be covertly, and by snatches.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p"> But <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">if</tei-hi> this view of
                    the all-popular <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> Shakspeare <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">be</tei-hi> seldom taken by his readers, and if very <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> few who
                    extol him, have ever read him deeply,<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">or, perhaps,</tei-hi> only
                    have seen him on the tricky stage<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">, (</tei-hi>which <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> alone made, and is still making him his
                    mere <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> mob renown<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">)
                    --</tei-hi> if few men have time, or patience, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> or palate <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi" data-empty=""></tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi> for the spiritual
                    truth as it is in <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    that</tei-hi> great genius; -- it is<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    then,</tei-hi> no matter of surprise <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> that <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">in a contemporaneous age</tei-hi>,
                    Nathaniel Hawthorne is a man, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">as yet, almost</tei-hi> utterly <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>mistaken among men. Here &
                    there, in some <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>quiet arm-chair in the noisy town, or some <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>deep nook
                    among the <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">noisless</tei-hi>
                    mountains, he may <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>be appreciated for something of what he is.</tei-p>
            </tei-div>

            <tei-div type="leaf" n="12" data-origname="div">
                </tei-div></tei-body></tei-text>

                    extol him, have ever read him deeply,<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">or, perhaps,</tei-hi> only
                    have seen him on the tricky stage<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">, (</tei-hi>which <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> alone made, and is still making him his
                    mere <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> mob renown<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">)
                    --</tei-hi> if few men have time, or patience, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> or palate <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi" data-empty=""></tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi> for the spiritual
                    truth as it is in <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    that</tei-hi> great genius; -- it is<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    then,</tei-hi> no matter of surprise <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> that <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">in a contemporaneous age</tei-hi>,
                    Nathaniel Hawthorne is a man, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">as yet, almost</tei-hi> utterly <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>mistaken among men. Here &
                    there, in some <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>quiet arm-chair in the noisy town, or some <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>deep nook
                    among the <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">noisless</tei-hi>
                    mountains, he may <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>be appreciated for something of what he is.</tei-p>
            </tei-div>

            <tei-div type="leaf" n="12" data-origname="div">
                </tei-div></tei-body></tei-text>

<tei-text data-xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="base" id="base" data-origname="text"><tei-body data-origname="body"><tei-div type="leaf" n="11" data-origname="div"><tei-pb facs="#f010" data-origname="pb" data-empty=""></tei-pb>

                <tei-p data-origname="p">
                    <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">much of the blind,
                    unbridled</tei-hi> admiration that has been heaped <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>upon Shakespeare, has been
                    lavished upon the <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> least part of him. And few of his endless <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    commentators & critics seem to have <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">remembered,</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">or even</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi>
               <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>that the
                    immediate products of a great mind <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> are not so great, as that undeveloped, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">(& sometimes
                    undevelopable)</tei-hi> yet <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> dimly-discern<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">able</tei-hi> greatness, to
                    which <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">these
                    immediate products</tei-hi> are but the infallible indices. In Shakespeare's <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    tomb lies infinitely more than <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Shakspeare</tei-hi> ever wrote. <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> And if I magnify Shakespeare,
                    it is not so much <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> for what he did<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">do,</tei-hi> as for what he
                    did not <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> do<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">or refrained from doing.</tei-hi>
                    For in this world of lies, Truth is <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">forced</tei-hi> to <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> fly like a scared white doe in the
                    woodlands; <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> and only by cunning glimpses will she reveal <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> herself,
                    as in Shakespeare and other <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">masters</tei-hi> of <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> the great <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Art</tei-hi> of Telling the
                    Truth<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,--</tei-hi>even though <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    it be covertly, and by snatches.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p"> But <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">if</tei-hi> this view of
                    the all-popular <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> Shakspeare <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">be</tei-hi> seldom taken by his readers, and if very <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> few who
                    extol him, have ever read him deeply,<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">or, perhaps,</tei-hi> only
                    have seen him on the tricky stage<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">, (</tei-hi>which <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> alone made, and is still making him his
                    mere <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> mob renown<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">)
                    --</tei-hi> if few men have time, or patience, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> or palate <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi" data-empty=""></tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi> for the spiritual
                    truth as it is in <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    that</tei-hi> great genius; -- it is<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    then,</tei-hi> no matter of surprise <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> that <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">in a contemporaneous age</tei-hi>,
                    Nathaniel Hawthorne is a man, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">as yet, almost</tei-hi> utterly <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>mistaken among men. Here &
                    there, in some <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>quiet arm-chair in the noisy town, or some <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>deep nook
                    among the <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">noisless</tei-hi>
                    mountains, he may <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>be appreciated for something of what he is.</tei-p>
            </tei-div>

            <tei-div type="leaf" n="12" data-origname="div">
                </tei-div></tei-body></tei-text>

                    it be covertly, and by snatches.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p"> But <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">if</tei-hi> this view of

                    --</tei-hi> if few men have time, or patience, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> or palate <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi" data-empty=""></tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi> for the spiritual
                    truth as it is in <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    that</tei-hi> great genius; -- it is<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    then,</tei-hi> no matter of surprise <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> that <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">in a contemporaneous age</tei-hi>,
                    Nathaniel Hawthorne is a man, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">as yet, almost</tei-hi> utterly <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>mistaken among men. Here &
                    there, in some <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>quiet arm-chair in the noisy town, or some <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>deep nook
                    among the <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">noisless</tei-hi>
                    mountains, he may <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>be appreciated for something of what he is.</tei-p>
            </tei-div>

            <tei-div type="leaf" n="12" data-origname="div">
                </tei-div></tei-body></tei-text>

<tei-text data-xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="base" id="base" data-origname="text"><tei-body data-origname="body"><tei-div type="leaf" n="11" data-origname="div"><tei-pb facs="#f010" data-origname="pb" data-empty=""></tei-pb>

                <tei-p data-origname="p">
                    <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">much of the blind,
                    unbridled</tei-hi> admiration that has been heaped <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>upon Shakespeare, has been
                    lavished upon the <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> least part of him. And few of his endless <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    commentators & critics seem to have <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">remembered,</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">or even</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi>
               <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>that the
                    immediate products of a great mind <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> are not so great, as that undeveloped, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">(& sometimes
                    undevelopable)</tei-hi> yet <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> dimly-discern<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">able</tei-hi> greatness, to
                    which <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">these
                    immediate products</tei-hi> are but the infallible indices. In Shakespeare's <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    tomb lies infinitely more than <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Shakspeare</tei-hi> ever wrote. <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> And if I magnify Shakespeare,
                    it is not so much <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> for what he did<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">do,</tei-hi> as for what he
                    did not <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> do<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">or refrained from doing.</tei-hi>
                    For in this world of lies, Truth is <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">forced</tei-hi> to <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> fly like a scared white doe in the
                    woodlands; <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> and only by cunning glimpses will she reveal <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> herself,
                    as in Shakespeare and other <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">masters</tei-hi> of <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> the great <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Art</tei-hi> of Telling the
                    Truth<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,--</tei-hi>even though <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    it be covertly, and by snatches.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p"> But <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">if</tei-hi> this view of
                    the all-popular <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> Shakspeare <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">be</tei-hi> seldom taken by his readers, and if very <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> few who
                    extol him, have ever read him deeply,<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">or, perhaps,</tei-hi> only
                    have seen him on the tricky stage<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">, (</tei-hi>which <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> alone made, and is still making him his
                    mere <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> mob renown<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">)
                    --</tei-hi> if few men have time, or patience, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> or palate <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi" data-empty=""></tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi> for the spiritual
                    truth as it is in <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    that</tei-hi> great genius; -- it is<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    then,</tei-hi> no matter of surprise <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> that <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">in a contemporaneous age</tei-hi>,
                    Nathaniel Hawthorne is a man, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">as yet, almost</tei-hi> utterly <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>mistaken among men. Here &
                    there, in some <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>quiet arm-chair in the noisy town, or some <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>deep nook
                    among the <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">noisless</tei-hi>
                    mountains, he may <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>be appreciated for something of what he is.</tei-p>
            </tei-div>

            <tei-div type="leaf" n="12" data-origname="div">
                </tei-div></tei-body></tei-text>

<tei-text data-xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="base" id="base" data-origname="text"><tei-body data-origname="body"><tei-div type="leaf" n="11" data-origname="div"><tei-pb facs="#f010" data-origname="pb" data-empty=""></tei-pb>

                    Truth<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,--</tei-hi>even though <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    it be covertly, and by snatches.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p"> But <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">if</tei-hi> this view of

               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    then,</tei-hi> no matter of surprise <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> that <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">in a contemporaneous age</tei-hi>,
                    Nathaniel Hawthorne is a man, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">as yet, almost</tei-hi> utterly <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>mistaken among men. Here &
                    there, in some <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>quiet arm-chair in the noisy town, or some <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>deep nook
                    among the <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">noisless</tei-hi>
                    mountains, he may <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>be appreciated for something of what he is.</tei-p>
            </tei-div>

            <tei-div type="leaf" n="12" data-origname="div">
                </tei-div></tei-body></tei-text>

<tei-text data-xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="base" id="base" data-origname="text"><tei-body data-origname="body"><tei-div type="leaf" n="11" data-origname="div"><tei-pb facs="#f010" data-origname="pb" data-empty=""></tei-pb>

                <tei-p data-origname="p">
                    <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">much of the blind,
                    unbridled</tei-hi> admiration that has been heaped <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>upon Shakespeare, has been
                    lavished upon the <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> least part of him. And few of his endless <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    commentators & critics seem to have <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">remembered,</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">or even</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi>
               <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>that the
                    immediate products of a great mind <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> are not so great, as that undeveloped, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">(& sometimes
                    undevelopable)</tei-hi> yet <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> dimly-discern<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">able</tei-hi> greatness, to
                    which <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">these
                    immediate products</tei-hi> are but the infallible indices. In Shakespeare's <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    tomb lies infinitely more than <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Shakspeare</tei-hi> ever wrote. <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> And if I magnify Shakespeare,
                    it is not so much <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> for what he did<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">do,</tei-hi> as for what he
                    did not <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> do<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">or refrained from doing.</tei-hi>
                    For in this world of lies, Truth is <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">forced</tei-hi> to <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> fly like a scared white doe in the
                    woodlands; <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> and only by cunning glimpses will she reveal <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> herself,
                    as in Shakespeare and other <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">masters</tei-hi> of <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> the great <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Art</tei-hi> of Telling the
                    Truth<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,--</tei-hi>even though <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    it be covertly, and by snatches.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p"> But <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">if</tei-hi> this view of
                    the all-popular <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> Shakspeare <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">be</tei-hi> seldom taken by his readers, and if very <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> few who
                    extol him, have ever read him deeply,<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">or, perhaps,</tei-hi> only
                    have seen him on the tricky stage<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">, (</tei-hi>which <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> alone made, and is still making him his
                    mere <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> mob renown<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">)
                    --</tei-hi> if few men have time, or patience, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> or palate <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi" data-empty=""></tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi> for the spiritual
                    truth as it is in <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    that</tei-hi> great genius; -- it is<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    then,</tei-hi> no matter of surprise <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> that <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">in a contemporaneous age</tei-hi>,
                    Nathaniel Hawthorne is a man, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">as yet, almost</tei-hi> utterly <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>mistaken among men. Here &
                    there, in some <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>quiet arm-chair in the noisy town, or some <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>deep nook
                    among the <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">noisless</tei-hi>
                    mountains, he may <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>be appreciated for something of what he is.</tei-p>
            </tei-div>

            <tei-div type="leaf" n="12" data-origname="div">
                </tei-div></tei-body></tei-text>

<tei-text data-xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="base" id="base" data-origname="text"><tei-body data-origname="body"><tei-div type="leaf" n="11" data-origname="div"><tei-pb facs="#f010" data-origname="pb" data-empty=""></tei-pb>

                    it be covertly, and by snatches.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p"> But <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">if</tei-hi> this view of
                    the all-popular <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> Shakspeare <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">be</tei-hi> seldom taken by his readers, and if very <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> few who

                    mountains, he may <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>be appreciated for something of what he is.</tei-p>

            <tei-div type="leaf" n="12" data-origname="div">
                </tei-div></tei-body></tei-text>

<tei-text data-xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="base" id="base" data-origname="text"><tei-body data-origname="body"><tei-div type="leaf" n="11" data-origname="div"><tei-pb facs="#f010" data-origname="pb" data-empty=""></tei-pb>

                <tei-p data-origname="p">
                    <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">much of the blind,
                    unbridled</tei-hi> admiration that has been heaped <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>upon Shakespeare, has been
                    lavished upon the <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> least part of him. And few of his endless <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    commentators & critics seem to have <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">remembered,</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">or even</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi>
               <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>that the
                    immediate products of a great mind <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> are not so great, as that undeveloped, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">(& sometimes
                    undevelopable)</tei-hi> yet <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> dimly-discern<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">able</tei-hi> greatness, to
                    which <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">these
                    immediate products</tei-hi> are but the infallible indices. In Shakespeare's <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    tomb lies infinitely more than <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Shakspeare</tei-hi> ever wrote. <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> And if I magnify Shakespeare,
                    it is not so much <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> for what he did<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">do,</tei-hi> as for what he
                    did not <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> do<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">or refrained from doing.</tei-hi>
                    For in this world of lies, Truth is <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">forced</tei-hi> to <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> fly like a scared white doe in the
                    woodlands; <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> and only by cunning glimpses will she reveal <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> herself,
                    as in Shakespeare and other <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">masters</tei-hi> of <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> the great <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Art</tei-hi> of Telling the
                    Truth<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,--</tei-hi>even though <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    it be covertly, and by snatches.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p"> But <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">if</tei-hi> this view of
                    the all-popular <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> Shakspeare <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">be</tei-hi> seldom taken by his readers, and if very <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> few who
                    extol him, have ever read him deeply,<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">or, perhaps,</tei-hi> only
                    have seen him on the tricky stage<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">, (</tei-hi>which <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> alone made, and is still making him his
                    mere <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> mob renown<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">)
                    --</tei-hi> if few men have time, or patience, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> or palate <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi" data-empty=""></tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi> for the spiritual
                    truth as it is in <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    that</tei-hi> great genius; -- it is<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    then,</tei-hi> no matter of surprise <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> that <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">in a contemporaneous age</tei-hi>,
                    Nathaniel Hawthorne is a man, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">as yet, almost</tei-hi> utterly <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>mistaken among men. Here &
                    there, in some <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>quiet arm-chair in the noisy town, or some <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>deep nook
                    among the <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">noisless</tei-hi>
                    mountains, he may <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>be appreciated for something of what he is.</tei-p>
            </tei-div>

            <tei-div type="leaf" n="12" data-origname="div">
                </tei-div></tei-body></tei-text>

<tei-text data-xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="base" id="base" data-origname="text"><tei-body data-origname="body"><tei-div type="leaf" n="11" data-origname="div"><tei-pb facs="#f010" data-origname="pb" data-empty=""></tei-pb>

                    unbridled</tei-hi> admiration that has been heaped <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>upon Shakespeare, has been
                    lavished upon the <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> least part of him. And few of his endless <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    commentators & critics seem to have <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">remembered,</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">or even</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi>
               <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>that the
                    immediate products of a great mind <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> are not so great, as that undeveloped, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">(& sometimes
                    undevelopable)</tei-hi> yet <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> dimly-discern<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">able</tei-hi> greatness, to
                    which <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">these
                    immediate products</tei-hi> are but the infallible indices. In Shakespeare's <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    tomb lies infinitely more than <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Shakspeare</tei-hi> ever wrote. <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> And if I magnify Shakespeare,
                    it is not so much <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> for what he did<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">do,</tei-hi> as for what he
                    did not <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> do<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">or refrained from doing.</tei-hi>
                    For in this world of lies, Truth is <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">forced</tei-hi> to <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> fly like a scared white doe in the
                    woodlands; <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> and only by cunning glimpses will she reveal <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> herself,
                    as in Shakespeare and other <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">masters</tei-hi> of <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> the great <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Art</tei-hi> of Telling the
                    Truth<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,--</tei-hi>even though <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    it be covertly, and by snatches.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p"> But <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">if</tei-hi> this view of
                    the all-popular <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> Shakspeare <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">be</tei-hi> seldom taken by his readers, and if very <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> few who
                    extol him, have ever read him deeply,<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">or, perhaps,</tei-hi> only
                    have seen him on the tricky stage<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">, (</tei-hi>which <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> alone made, and is still making him his
                    mere <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> mob renown<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">)
                    --</tei-hi> if few men have time, or patience, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> or palate <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi" data-empty=""></tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi> for the spiritual
                    truth as it is in <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    that</tei-hi> great genius; -- it is<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    then,</tei-hi> no matter of surprise <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> that <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">in a contemporaneous age</tei-hi>,
                    Nathaniel Hawthorne is a man, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">as yet, almost</tei-hi> utterly <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>mistaken among men. Here &
                    there, in some <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>quiet arm-chair in the noisy town, or some <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>deep nook
                    among the <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">noisless</tei-hi>
                    mountains, he may <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>be appreciated for something of what he is.</tei-p>
            </tei-div>

            <tei-div type="leaf" n="12" data-origname="div">
                </tei-div></tei-body></tei-text>

               <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>that the
                    immediate products of a great mind <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> are not so great, as that undeveloped, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">(& sometimes
                    undevelopable)</tei-hi> yet <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> dimly-discern<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">able</tei-hi> greatness, to
                    which <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">these
                    immediate products</tei-hi> are but the infallible indices. In Shakespeare's <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    tomb lies infinitely more than <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Shakspeare</tei-hi> ever wrote. <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> And if I magnify Shakespeare,
                    it is not so much <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> for what he did<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">do,</tei-hi> as for what he
                    did not <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> do<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">or refrained from doing.</tei-hi>
                    For in this world of lies, Truth is <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">forced</tei-hi> to <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> fly like a scared white doe in the
                    woodlands; <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> and only by cunning glimpses will she reveal <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> herself,
                    as in Shakespeare and other <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">masters</tei-hi> of <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> the great <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Art</tei-hi> of Telling the
                    Truth<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,--</tei-hi>even though <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    it be covertly, and by snatches.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p"> But <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">if</tei-hi> this view of
                    the all-popular <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> Shakspeare <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">be</tei-hi> seldom taken by his readers, and if very <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> few who
                    extol him, have ever read him deeply,<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">or, perhaps,</tei-hi> only
                    have seen him on the tricky stage<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">, (</tei-hi>which <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> alone made, and is still making him his
                    mere <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> mob renown<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">)
                    --</tei-hi> if few men have time, or patience, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> or palate <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi" data-empty=""></tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi> for the spiritual
                    truth as it is in <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    that</tei-hi> great genius; -- it is<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    then,</tei-hi> no matter of surprise <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> that <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">in a contemporaneous age</tei-hi>,
                    Nathaniel Hawthorne is a man, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">as yet, almost</tei-hi> utterly <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>mistaken among men. Here &
                    there, in some <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>quiet arm-chair in the noisy town, or some <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>deep nook
                    among the <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">noisless</tei-hi>
                    mountains, he may <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>be appreciated for something of what he is.</tei-p>
            </tei-div>

            <tei-div type="leaf" n="12" data-origname="div">
                </tei-div></tei-body></tei-text>

<tei-text data-xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="base" id="base" data-origname="text"><tei-body data-origname="body"><tei-div type="leaf" n="11" data-origname="div"><tei-pb facs="#f010" data-origname="pb" data-empty=""></tei-pb>

                <tei-p data-origname="p"> But <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">if</tei-hi> this view of
                    the all-popular <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> Shakspeare <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">be</tei-hi> seldom taken by his readers, and if very <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> few who

               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">or, perhaps,</tei-hi> only

                    immediate products</tei-hi> are but the infallible indices. In Shakespeare's <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    tomb lies infinitely more than <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Shakspeare</tei-hi> ever wrote. <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> And if I magnify Shakespeare,
                    it is not so much <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> for what he did<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">do,</tei-hi> as for what he
                    did not <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> do<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">or refrained from doing.</tei-hi>
                    For in this world of lies, Truth is <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">forced</tei-hi> to <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> fly like a scared white doe in the
                    woodlands; <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> and only by cunning glimpses will she reveal <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> herself,
                    as in Shakespeare and other <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">masters</tei-hi> of <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> the great <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Art</tei-hi> of Telling the
                    Truth<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,--</tei-hi>even though <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    it be covertly, and by snatches.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p"> But <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">if</tei-hi> this view of
                    the all-popular <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> Shakspeare <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">be</tei-hi> seldom taken by his readers, and if very <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> few who
                    extol him, have ever read him deeply,<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">or, perhaps,</tei-hi> only
                    have seen him on the tricky stage<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">, (</tei-hi>which <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> alone made, and is still making him his
                    mere <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> mob renown<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">)
                    --</tei-hi> if few men have time, or patience, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> or palate <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi" data-empty=""></tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi> for the spiritual
                    truth as it is in <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    that</tei-hi> great genius; -- it is<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    then,</tei-hi> no matter of surprise <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> that <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">in a contemporaneous age</tei-hi>,
                    Nathaniel Hawthorne is a man, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">as yet, almost</tei-hi> utterly <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>mistaken among men. Here &
                    there, in some <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>quiet arm-chair in the noisy town, or some <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>deep nook
                    among the <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">noisless</tei-hi>
                    mountains, he may <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>be appreciated for something of what he is.</tei-p>
            </tei-div>

            <tei-div type="leaf" n="12" data-origname="div">
                </tei-div></tei-body></tei-text>

<tei-text data-xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="base" id="base" data-origname="text"><tei-body data-origname="body"><tei-div type="leaf" n="11" data-origname="div"><tei-pb facs="#f010" data-origname="pb" data-empty=""></tei-pb>

                <tei-p data-origname="p">
                    <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">much of the blind,
                    unbridled</tei-hi> admiration that has been heaped <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>upon Shakespeare, has been
                    lavished upon the <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> least part of him. And few of his endless <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    commentators & critics seem to have <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">remembered,</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">or even</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi>
               <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>that the
                    immediate products of a great mind <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> are not so great, as that undeveloped, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">(& sometimes
                    undevelopable)</tei-hi> yet <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> dimly-discern<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">able</tei-hi> greatness, to
                    which <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">these
                    immediate products</tei-hi> are but the infallible indices. In Shakespeare's <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    tomb lies infinitely more than <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Shakspeare</tei-hi> ever wrote. <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> And if I magnify Shakespeare,
                    it is not so much <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> for what he did<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">do,</tei-hi> as for what he
                    did not <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> do<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">or refrained from doing.</tei-hi>
                    For in this world of lies, Truth is <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">forced</tei-hi> to <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> fly like a scared white doe in the
                    woodlands; <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> and only by cunning glimpses will she reveal <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> herself,
                    as in Shakespeare and other <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">masters</tei-hi> of <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> the great <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Art</tei-hi> of Telling the
                    Truth<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,--</tei-hi>even though <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    it be covertly, and by snatches.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p"> But <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">if</tei-hi> this view of
                    the all-popular <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> Shakspeare <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">be</tei-hi> seldom taken by his readers, and if very <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> few who
                    extol him, have ever read him deeply,<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">or, perhaps,</tei-hi> only
                    have seen him on the tricky stage<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">, (</tei-hi>which <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> alone made, and is still making him his
                    mere <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> mob renown<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">)
                    --</tei-hi> if few men have time, or patience, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> or palate <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi" data-empty=""></tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi> for the spiritual
                    truth as it is in <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    that</tei-hi> great genius; -- it is<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    then,</tei-hi> no matter of surprise <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> that <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">in a contemporaneous age</tei-hi>,
                    Nathaniel Hawthorne is a man, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">as yet, almost</tei-hi> utterly <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>mistaken among men. Here &
                    there, in some <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>quiet arm-chair in the noisy town, or some <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>deep nook
                    among the <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">noisless</tei-hi>
                    mountains, he may <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>be appreciated for something of what he is.</tei-p>
            </tei-div>

                </tei-div></tei-body></tei-text>

                    did not <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> do<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">or refrained from doing.</tei-hi>
                    For in this world of lies, Truth is <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">forced</tei-hi> to <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> fly like a scared white doe in the
                    woodlands; <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> and only by cunning glimpses will she reveal <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> herself,
                    as in Shakespeare and other <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">masters</tei-hi> of <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> the great <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Art</tei-hi> of Telling the
                    Truth<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,--</tei-hi>even though <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    it be covertly, and by snatches.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p"> But <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">if</tei-hi> this view of
                    the all-popular <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> Shakspeare <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">be</tei-hi> seldom taken by his readers, and if very <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> few who
                    extol him, have ever read him deeply,<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">or, perhaps,</tei-hi> only
                    have seen him on the tricky stage<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">, (</tei-hi>which <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> alone made, and is still making him his
                    mere <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> mob renown<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">)
                    --</tei-hi> if few men have time, or patience, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> or palate <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi" data-empty=""></tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi> for the spiritual
                    truth as it is in <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    that</tei-hi> great genius; -- it is<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    then,</tei-hi> no matter of surprise <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> that <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">in a contemporaneous age</tei-hi>,
                    Nathaniel Hawthorne is a man, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">as yet, almost</tei-hi> utterly <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>mistaken among men. Here &
                    there, in some <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>quiet arm-chair in the noisy town, or some <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>deep nook
                    among the <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">noisless</tei-hi>
                    mountains, he may <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>be appreciated for something of what he is.</tei-p>
            </tei-div>

            <tei-div type="leaf" n="12" data-origname="div">
                </tei-div></tei-body></tei-text>

<tei-text data-xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="base" id="base" data-origname="text"><tei-body data-origname="body"><tei-div type="leaf" n="11" data-origname="div"><tei-pb facs="#f010" data-origname="pb" data-empty=""></tei-pb>

                <tei-p data-origname="p">
                    <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">much of the blind,
                    unbridled</tei-hi> admiration that has been heaped <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>upon Shakespeare, has been
                    lavished upon the <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> least part of him. And few of his endless <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    commentators & critics seem to have <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">remembered,</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">or even</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi>
               <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>that the
                    immediate products of a great mind <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> are not so great, as that undeveloped, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">(& sometimes
                    undevelopable)</tei-hi> yet <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> dimly-discern<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">able</tei-hi> greatness, to
                    which <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">these
                    immediate products</tei-hi> are but the infallible indices. In Shakespeare's <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    tomb lies infinitely more than <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Shakspeare</tei-hi> ever wrote. <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> And if I magnify Shakespeare,
                    it is not so much <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> for what he did<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">do,</tei-hi> as for what he
                    did not <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> do<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">or refrained from doing.</tei-hi>
                    For in this world of lies, Truth is <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">forced</tei-hi> to <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> fly like a scared white doe in the
                    woodlands; <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> and only by cunning glimpses will she reveal <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> herself,
                    as in Shakespeare and other <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">masters</tei-hi> of <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> the great <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Art</tei-hi> of Telling the
                    Truth<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,--</tei-hi>even though <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
                    it be covertly, and by snatches.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p"> But <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">if</tei-hi> this view of
                    the all-popular <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> Shakspeare <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">be</tei-hi> seldom taken by his readers, and if very <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> few who
                    extol him, have ever read him deeply,<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">or, perhaps,</tei-hi> only
                    have seen him on the tricky stage<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">, (</tei-hi>which <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> alone made, and is still making him his
                    mere <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> mob renown<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">)
                    --</tei-hi> if few men have time, or patience, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> or palate <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi" data-empty=""></tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi> for the spiritual
                    truth as it is in <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    that</tei-hi> great genius; -- it is<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    then,</tei-hi> no matter of surprise <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> that <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">in a contemporaneous age</tei-hi>,
                    Nathaniel Hawthorne is a man, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">as yet, almost</tei-hi> utterly <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>mistaken among men. Here &
                    there, in some <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>quiet arm-chair in the noisy town, or some <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>deep nook
                    among the <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">noisless</tei-hi>
                    mountains, he may <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>be appreciated for something of what he is.</tei-p>
            </tei-div>

            <tei-div type="leaf" n="12" data-origname="div">
                </tei-div></tei-body></tei-text>

               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">or refrained from doing.</tei-hi>
