<tei-text data-xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="base" id="base" data-origname="text"><tei-body data-origname="body"><tei-div type="leaf" n="12" data-origname="div"><tei-pb facs="#f011" data-origname="pb" data-empty=""></tei-pb>

                <tei-p data-origname="p">But unlike Shakespeare, who was forced <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>to <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">the contrary course</tei-hi>
                    by circumstances, Hawthorne <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">(</tei-hi>either from <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>simple disinclination, or else from
                    inaptitude) <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>refrains from all the <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">popularizing noise</tei-hi>
                    and show of <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>broad farce, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">&</tei-hi> blood-besmeared tragedy; <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>content with the
                    still, rich utterance<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">s</tei-hi>
                    of a <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>great intellect in repose, and which sends <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>few thoughts into
                    circulation, except they be <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>arterialized <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">at</tei-hi> his large warm
                    lungs, and <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>expanded in his honest heart.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Nor need you <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>fix upon that blackness in him, if it suit <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>you not. Nor,
                    indeed, will all readers discern <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>it, for it is, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">mostly,</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">insinuated</tei-hi> to those
                    who may <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>best undersand it, and account for it; it is <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>not obtruded
                    upon every one alike.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p"> Some may start to read of Shakespeare and <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>Hawthorne on the same page. They
                    may say, that if <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>an illustration were needed, a lesser light might have <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>sufficed
                    to elucidate this Hawthorne, this <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">small</tei-hi> man of <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>yesterday. But I am not, willingly, one
                    of those, who, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>as touching Shakespeare at least, exemplify the <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>maxim
                    of Rochefoucault, that "we exalt the reputation <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>of some, in order to
                    depress that of others"<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    ;--</tei-hi> who, to <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>teach all <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi"> noble-souled aspirants</tei-hi> that there is no hope for them, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>pronounce
                    Shakespeare absolutely unapproachable. <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">But</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Shakespeare</tei-hi> has
                    been approached. There are minds <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>that have gone as <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">far</tei-hi> as Shakespeare
                    into <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>the universe. And hardly a mortal man, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">who,</tei-hi>
               <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>at some
                    time or other, has not felt <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>as great thoughts in him as any you will find <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>in

                    inferentially</tei-hi> malign mankind</tei-p>

               <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>at some

                    Hamlet. We must not <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">

<tei-text data-xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="base" id="base" data-origname="text"><tei-body data-origname="body"><tei-div type="leaf" n="12" data-origname="div"><tei-pb facs="#f011" data-origname="pb" data-empty=""></tei-pb>

                <tei-p data-origname="p">But unlike Shakespeare, who was forced <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>to <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">the contrary course</tei-hi>
                    by circumstances, Hawthorne <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">(</tei-hi>either from <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>simple disinclination, or else from
                    inaptitude) <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>refrains from all the <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">popularizing noise</tei-hi>
                    and show of <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>broad farce, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">&</tei-hi> blood-besmeared tragedy; <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>content with the
                    still, rich utterance<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">s</tei-hi>
                    of a <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>great intellect in repose, and which sends <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>few thoughts into
                    circulation, except they be <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>arterialized <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">at</tei-hi> his large warm
                    lungs, and <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>expanded in his honest heart.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Nor need you <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>fix upon that blackness in him, if it suit <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>you not. Nor,
                    indeed, will all readers discern <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>it, for it is, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">mostly,</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">insinuated</tei-hi> to those
                    who may <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>best undersand it, and account for it; it is <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>not obtruded
                    upon every one alike.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p"> Some may start to read of Shakespeare and <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>Hawthorne on the same page. They
                    may say, that if <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>an illustration were needed, a lesser light might have <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>sufficed
                    to elucidate this Hawthorne, this <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">small</tei-hi> man of <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>yesterday. But I am not, willingly, one
                    of those, who, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>as touching Shakespeare at least, exemplify the <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>maxim
                    of Rochefoucault, that "we exalt the reputation <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>of some, in order to
                    depress that of others"<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    ;--</tei-hi> who, to <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>teach all <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi"> noble-souled aspirants</tei-hi> that there is no hope for them, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>pronounce
                    Shakespeare absolutely unapproachable. <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">But</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Shakespeare</tei-hi> has
                    been approached. There are minds <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>that have gone as <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">far</tei-hi> as Shakespeare

                    been approached. There are minds <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>that have gone as <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">far</tei-hi> as Shakespeare
                    into <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>the universe. And hardly a mortal man, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">who,</tei-hi>
               <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>at some
                    time or other, has not felt <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>as great thoughts in him as any you will find <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>in
                    Hamlet. We must not <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">

<tei-text data-xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="base" id="base" data-origname="text"><tei-body data-origname="body"><tei-div type="leaf" n="12" data-origname="div"><tei-pb facs="#f011" data-origname="pb" data-empty=""></tei-pb>

                <tei-p data-origname="p">But unlike Shakespeare, who was forced <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>to <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">the contrary course</tei-hi>
                    by circumstances, Hawthorne <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">(</tei-hi>either from <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>simple disinclination, or else from
                    inaptitude) <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>refrains from all the <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">popularizing noise</tei-hi>
                    and show of <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>broad farce, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">&</tei-hi> blood-besmeared tragedy; <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>content with the
                    still, rich utterance<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">s</tei-hi>
                    of a <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>great intellect in repose, and which sends <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>few thoughts into
                    circulation, except they be <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>arterialized <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">at</tei-hi> his large warm
                    lungs, and <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>expanded in his honest heart.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Nor need you <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>fix upon that blackness in him, if it suit <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>you not. Nor,
                    indeed, will all readers discern <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>it, for it is, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">mostly,</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">insinuated</tei-hi> to those
                    who may <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>best undersand it, and account for it; it is <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>not obtruded
                    upon every one alike.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p"> Some may start to read of Shakespeare and <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>Hawthorne on the same page. They
                    may say, that if <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>an illustration were needed, a lesser light might have <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>sufficed
                    to elucidate this Hawthorne, this <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">small</tei-hi> man of <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>yesterday. But I am not, willingly, one
                    of those, who, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>as touching Shakespeare at least, exemplify the <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>maxim
                    of Rochefoucault, that "we exalt the reputation <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>of some, in order to
                    depress that of others"<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    ;--</tei-hi> who, to <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>teach all <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi"> noble-souled aspirants</tei-hi> that there is no hope for them, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>pronounce
                    Shakespeare absolutely unapproachable. <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">But</tei-hi>

                    inferentially</tei-hi> malign mankind</tei-p>

               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">But</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Shakespeare</tei-hi> has
                    been approached. There are minds <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>that have gone as <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">far</tei-hi> as Shakespeare
                    into <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>the universe. And hardly a mortal man, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">who,</tei-hi>

<tei-text data-xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="base" id="base" data-origname="text"><tei-body data-origname="body"><tei-div type="leaf" n="12" data-origname="div"><tei-pb facs="#f011" data-origname="pb" data-empty=""></tei-pb>

                <tei-p data-origname="p">But unlike Shakespeare, who was forced <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>to <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">the contrary course</tei-hi>
                    by circumstances, Hawthorne <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">(</tei-hi>either from <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>simple disinclination, or else from
                    inaptitude) <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>refrains from all the <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">popularizing noise</tei-hi>
                    and show of <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>broad farce, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">&</tei-hi> blood-besmeared tragedy; <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>content with the
                    still, rich utterance<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">s</tei-hi>
                    of a <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>great intellect in repose, and which sends <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>few thoughts into
                    circulation, except they be <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>arterialized <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">at</tei-hi> his large warm
                    lungs, and <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>expanded in his honest heart.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Nor need you <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>fix upon that blackness in him, if it suit <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>you not. Nor,
                    indeed, will all readers discern <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>it, for it is, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">mostly,</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">insinuated</tei-hi> to those
                    who may <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>best undersand it, and account for it; it is <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>not obtruded
                    upon every one alike.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p"> Some may start to read of Shakespeare and <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>Hawthorne on the same page. They
                    may say, that if <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>an illustration were needed, a lesser light might have <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>sufficed
                    to elucidate this Hawthorne, this <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">small</tei-hi> man of <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>yesterday. But I am not, willingly, one
                    of those, who, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>as touching Shakespeare at least, exemplify the <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>maxim
                    of Rochefoucault, that "we exalt the reputation <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>of some, in order to
                    depress that of others"<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    ;--</tei-hi> who, to <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>teach all <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi"> noble-souled aspirants</tei-hi> that there is no hope for them, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>pronounce
                    Shakespeare absolutely unapproachable. <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>

                    Shakespeare absolutely unapproachable. <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">But</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Shakespeare</tei-hi> has
                    been approached. There are minds <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>that have gone as <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">far</tei-hi> as Shakespeare
                    into <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>the universe. And hardly a mortal man, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">who,</tei-hi>

<tei-text data-xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="base" id="base" data-origname="text"><tei-body data-origname="body"><tei-div type="leaf" n="12" data-origname="div"><tei-pb facs="#f011" data-origname="pb" data-empty=""></tei-pb>

                <tei-p data-origname="p">But unlike Shakespeare, who was forced <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>to <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">the contrary course</tei-hi>
                    by circumstances, Hawthorne <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">(</tei-hi>either from <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>simple disinclination, or else from
                    inaptitude) <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>refrains from all the <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">popularizing noise</tei-hi>
                    and show of <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>broad farce, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">&</tei-hi> blood-besmeared tragedy; <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>content with the
                    still, rich utterance<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">s</tei-hi>
                    of a <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>great intellect in repose, and which sends <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>few thoughts into
                    circulation, except they be <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>arterialized <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">at</tei-hi> his large warm
                    lungs, and <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>expanded in his honest heart.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Nor need you <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>fix upon that blackness in him, if it suit <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>you not. Nor,
                    indeed, will all readers discern <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>it, for it is, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">mostly,</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">insinuated</tei-hi> to those
                    who may <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>best undersand it, and account for it; it is <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>not obtruded
                    upon every one alike.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p"> Some may start to read of Shakespeare and <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>Hawthorne on the same page. They
                    may say, that if <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>an illustration were needed, a lesser light might have <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>sufficed
                    to elucidate this Hawthorne, this <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">small</tei-hi> man of <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>yesterday. But I am not, willingly, one
                    of those, who, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>as touching Shakespeare at least, exemplify the <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>maxim
                    of Rochefoucault, that "we exalt the reputation <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>of some, in order to
                    depress that of others"<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    ;--</tei-hi> who, to <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>teach all <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi"> noble-souled aspirants</tei-hi> that there is no hope for them, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>pronounce
                    Shakespeare absolutely unapproachable. <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>

                    of Rochefoucault, that "we exalt the reputation <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>of some, in order to
                    depress that of others"<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    ;--</tei-hi> who, to <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>teach all <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi"> noble-souled aspirants</tei-hi> that there is no hope for them, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>pronounce
                    Shakespeare absolutely unapproachable. <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">But</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Shakespeare</tei-hi> has
                    been approached. There are minds <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>that have gone as <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">far</tei-hi> as Shakespeare
                    into <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>the universe. And hardly a mortal man, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">who,</tei-hi>

<tei-text data-xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="base" id="base" data-origname="text"><tei-body data-origname="body"><tei-div type="leaf" n="12" data-origname="div"><tei-pb facs="#f011" data-origname="pb" data-empty=""></tei-pb>

                <tei-p data-origname="p">But unlike Shakespeare, who was forced <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>to <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">the contrary course</tei-hi>
                    by circumstances, Hawthorne <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">(</tei-hi>either from <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>simple disinclination, or else from
                    inaptitude) <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>refrains from all the <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">popularizing noise</tei-hi>
                    and show of <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>broad farce, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">&</tei-hi> blood-besmeared tragedy; <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>content with the
                    still, rich utterance<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">s</tei-hi>
                    of a <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>great intellect in repose, and which sends <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>few thoughts into
                    circulation, except they be <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>arterialized <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">at</tei-hi> his large warm
                    lungs, and <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>expanded in his honest heart.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Nor need you <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>fix upon that blackness in him, if it suit <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>you not. Nor,
                    indeed, will all readers discern <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>it, for it is, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">mostly,</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">insinuated</tei-hi> to those
                    who may <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>best undersand it, and account for it; it is <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>not obtruded
                    upon every one alike.</tei-p>

                    may say, that if <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>an illustration were needed, a lesser light might have <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>sufficed
                    to elucidate this Hawthorne, this <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">small</tei-hi> man of <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>yesterday. But I am not, willingly, one

                    of Rochefoucault, that "we exalt the reputation <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>of some, in order to

                    to elucidate this Hawthorne, this <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">small</tei-hi> man of <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>yesterday. But I am not, willingly, one
                    of those, who, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>as touching Shakespeare at least, exemplify the <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>maxim
                    of Rochefoucault, that "we exalt the reputation <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>of some, in order to
                    depress that of others"<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    ;--</tei-hi> who, to <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>teach all <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi"> noble-souled aspirants</tei-hi> that there is no hope for them, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>pronounce
                    Shakespeare absolutely unapproachable. <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">But</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Shakespeare</tei-hi> has
                    been approached. There are minds <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>that have gone as <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">far</tei-hi> as Shakespeare
                    into <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>the universe. And hardly a mortal man, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">who,</tei-hi>
               <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>at some

<tei-text data-xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="base" id="base" data-origname="text"><tei-body data-origname="body"><tei-div type="leaf" n="12" data-origname="div"><tei-pb facs="#f011" data-origname="pb" data-empty=""></tei-pb>

                <tei-p data-origname="p">But unlike Shakespeare, who was forced <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>to <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">the contrary course</tei-hi>
                    by circumstances, Hawthorne <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">(</tei-hi>either from <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>simple disinclination, or else from
                    inaptitude) <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>refrains from all the <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">popularizing noise</tei-hi>
                    and show of <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>broad farce, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">&</tei-hi> blood-besmeared tragedy; <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>content with the
                    still, rich utterance<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">s</tei-hi>
                    of a <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>great intellect in repose, and which sends <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>few thoughts into
                    circulation, except they be <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>arterialized <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">at</tei-hi> his large warm
                    lungs, and <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>expanded in his honest heart.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Nor need you <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>fix upon that blackness in him, if it suit <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>you not. Nor,
                    indeed, will all readers discern <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>it, for it is, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">mostly,</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">insinuated</tei-hi> to those
                    who may <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>best undersand it, and account for it; it is <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>not obtruded
                    upon every one alike.</tei-p>

                    of Rochefoucault, that "we exalt the reputation <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>of some, in order to

                    to elucidate this Hawthorne, this <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">small</tei-hi> man of <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>yesterday. But I am not, willingly, one

                    inaptitude) <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>refrains from all the <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">popularizing noise</tei-hi>
                    and show of <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>broad farce, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">&</tei-hi> blood-besmeared tragedy; <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>content with the

                    of a <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>great intellect in repose, and which sends <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>few thoughts into
                    circulation, except they be <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>arterialized <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">at</tei-hi> his large warm
                    lungs, and <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>expanded in his honest heart.</tei-p>

                    who may <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>best undersand it, and account for it; it is <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>not obtruded
                    upon every one alike.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p"> Some may start to read of Shakespeare and <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>Hawthorne on the same page. They
                    may say, that if <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>an illustration were needed, a lesser light might have <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>sufficed
                    to elucidate this Hawthorne, this <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">small</tei-hi> man of <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>yesterday. But I am not, willingly, one
                    of those, who, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>as touching Shakespeare at least, exemplify the <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>maxim
                    of Rochefoucault, that "we exalt the reputation <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>of some, in order to
                    depress that of others"<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    ;--</tei-hi> who, to <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>teach all <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi"> noble-souled aspirants</tei-hi> that there is no hope for them, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>pronounce
                    Shakespeare absolutely unapproachable. <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">But</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Shakespeare</tei-hi> has
                    been approached. There are minds <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>that have gone as <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">far</tei-hi> as Shakespeare
                    into <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>the universe. And hardly a mortal man, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">who,</tei-hi>
               <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>at some
                    time or other, has not felt <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>as great thoughts in him as any you will find <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>in
                    Hamlet. We must not <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">

<tei-text data-xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="base" id="base" data-origname="text"><tei-body data-origname="body"><tei-div type="leaf" n="12" data-origname="div"><tei-pb facs="#f011" data-origname="pb" data-empty=""></tei-pb>

                <tei-p data-origname="p">But unlike Shakespeare, who was forced <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>to <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">the contrary course</tei-hi>
                    by circumstances, Hawthorne <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">(</tei-hi>either from <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>simple disinclination, or else from
                    inaptitude) <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>refrains from all the <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">popularizing noise</tei-hi>
                    and show of <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>broad farce, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">&</tei-hi> blood-besmeared tragedy; <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>content with the
                    still, rich utterance<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">s</tei-hi>
                    of a <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>great intellect in repose, and which sends <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>few thoughts into
                    circulation, except they be <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>arterialized <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">at</tei-hi> his large warm
                    lungs, and <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>expanded in his honest heart.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Nor need you <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>fix upon that blackness in him, if it suit <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>you not. Nor,
                    indeed, will all readers discern <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>it, for it is, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">mostly,</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">insinuated</tei-hi> to those
                    who may <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>best undersand it, and account for it; it is <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>not obtruded
                    upon every one alike.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p"> Some may start to read of Shakespeare and <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>Hawthorne on the same page. They
                    may say, that if <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>an illustration were needed, a lesser light might have <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>sufficed
                    to elucidate this Hawthorne, this <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">small</tei-hi> man of <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>yesterday. But I am not, willingly, one
                    of those, who, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>as touching Shakespeare at least, exemplify the <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>maxim
                    of Rochefoucault, that "we exalt the reputation <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>of some, in order to
                    depress that of others"<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    ;--</tei-hi> who, to <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>teach all <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi"> noble-souled aspirants</tei-hi> that there is no hope for them, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>pronounce
                    Shakespeare absolutely unapproachable. <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">But</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">Shakespeare</tei-hi> has
                    been approached. There are minds <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>that have gone as <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">far</tei-hi> as Shakespeare
                    into <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>the universe. And hardly a mortal man, <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">who,</tei-hi>
               <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>at some
                    time or other, has not felt <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>as great thoughts in him as any you will find <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>in
                    Hamlet. We must not <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    inferentially</tei-hi> malign mankind</tei-p>
            </tei-div>

<tei-text data-xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="base" id="base" data-origname="text"><tei-body data-origname="body"><tei-div type="leaf" n="13" data-origname="div"><tei-pb facs="#f012" data-origname="pb" data-empty=""></tei-pb>

                <tei-p data-origname="p">for the sake of any one man, whoever he <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>may be. This is too cheap a
                    purchase of contentment <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>for conscious mediocrity to make. Besides, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>this
                    absolute and unconditional adoration of <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>Shakespeare has grown to be a part
                    of our <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>Anglo Saxon superstition<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">s</tei-hi>. The <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">T</tei-hi>hirty <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">N</tei-hi>ine articles are <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>now <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">F</tei-hi>orty. Intolerance
                    has come to exist in <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>this matter.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">You must believe in Shakespeare<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">'s</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    unapproachability,</tei-hi> or <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>quit the country. But what sort of a belief <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>is
                    this for an American, a man who is bound <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>to carry republican progress<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">-iveness</tei-hi> into <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">L</tei-hi>itera-<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>ture,
                    as well as into <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">L</tei-hi>ife?
                    Believe me, my <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>friends, that <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                        <tei-hi rend="bold" data-origname="hi">men</tei-hi> not very much inferior to</tei-hi> Shakespeare<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi> are this day
                    being born <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>on the banks of the Ohio. And the day will <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> come, when
                    you shall say who reads a book <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>by an Englishman <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">that is a modern?</tei-hi>
                    The great mistake <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>seems to be, that even with those Americans <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>who
                    look forward <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">to</tei-hi> the
                    coming of a <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>great <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    literary</tei-hi> genius among us, they somehow fancy he <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>will come in the
                    costume of Queen Elizabeth's <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>day,-- be a writer of dramas founded upon <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>old
                    English history, or the tales of Boccaccio. <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>Whereas, great geniuses are
                    part<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">s</tei-hi> of the times; <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>they
                    themselves are the times; and possess a <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>correspondent coloring. It is of a <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">piece</tei-hi> with <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">t</tei-hi>he Jews, who <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>while
                    their Shiloh was meekly walking in <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>their streets, were still praying for
                    his magnifi-<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>cent coming; looking for him in a chariot, who <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>was
                    already among them on an ass. Nor must we <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>forget, that, in his own
                    life-time, Shakespeare was</tei-p>
            </tei-div>

            <tei-div type="leaf" n="14" data-origname="div">
                </tei-div></tei-body></tei-text>

                    this for an American, a man who is bound <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>to carry republican progress<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">-iveness</tei-hi> into <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">L</tei-hi>itera-<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>ture,
                    as well as into <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">L</tei-hi>ife?
                    Believe me, my <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>friends, that <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                        <tei-hi rend="bold" data-origname="hi">men</tei-hi> not very much inferior to</tei-hi> Shakespeare<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi> are this day
                    being born <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>on the banks of the Ohio. And the day will <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> come, when
                    you shall say who reads a book <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>by an Englishman <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">that is a modern?</tei-hi>
                    The great mistake <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>seems to be, that even with those Americans <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>who
                    look forward <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">to</tei-hi> the
                    coming of a <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>great <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    literary</tei-hi> genius among us, they somehow fancy he <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>will come in the
                    costume of Queen Elizabeth's <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>day,-- be a writer of dramas founded upon <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>old
                    English history, or the tales of Boccaccio. <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>Whereas, great geniuses are
                    part<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">s</tei-hi> of the times; <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>they
                    themselves are the times; and possess a <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>correspondent coloring. It is of a <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">piece</tei-hi> with <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">t</tei-hi>he Jews, who <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>while
                    their Shiloh was meekly walking in <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>their streets, were still praying for
                    his magnifi-<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>cent coming; looking for him in a chariot, who <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>was
                    already among them on an ass. Nor must we <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>forget, that, in his own
                    life-time, Shakespeare was</tei-p>

Intolerance
                    has come to exist in <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>this matter.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">You must believe in Shakespeare<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">'s</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    unapproachability,</tei-hi> or <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>quit the country. But what sort of a belief <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>is
                    this for an American, a man who is bound <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>to carry republican progress<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">-iveness</tei-hi> into <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">L</tei-hi>itera-<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>ture,
                    as well as into <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">L</tei-hi>ife?
                    Believe me, my <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>friends, that <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                        <tei-hi rend="bold" data-origname="hi">men</tei-hi> not very much inferior to</tei-hi> Shakespeare<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi> are this day
                    being born <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>on the banks of the Ohio. And the day will <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> come, when
                    you shall say who reads a book <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>by an Englishman <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">that is a modern?</tei-hi>
                    The great mistake <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>seems to be, that even with those Americans <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>who
                    look forward <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">to</tei-hi> the
                    coming of a <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>great <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    literary</tei-hi> genius among us, they somehow fancy he <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>will come in the
                    costume of Queen Elizabeth's <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>day,-- be a writer of dramas founded upon <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>old
                    English history, or the tales of Boccaccio. <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>Whereas, great geniuses are
                    part<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">s</tei-hi> of the times; <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>they
                    themselves are the times; and possess a <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>correspondent coloring. It is of a <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">piece</tei-hi> with <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">t</tei-hi>he Jews, who <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>while
                    their Shiloh was meekly walking in <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>their streets, were still praying for
                    his magnifi-<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>cent coming; looking for him in a chariot, who <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>was
                    already among them on an ass. Nor must we <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>forget, that, in his own
                    life-time, Shakespeare was</tei-p>
            </tei-div>

<tei-text data-xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="base" id="base" data-origname="text"><tei-body data-origname="body"><tei-div type="leaf" n="13" data-origname="div"><tei-pb facs="#f012" data-origname="pb" data-empty=""></tei-pb>

                <tei-p data-origname="p">for the sake of any one man, whoever he <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>may be. This is too cheap a
                    purchase of contentment <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>for conscious mediocrity to make. Besides, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>this
                    absolute and unconditional adoration of <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>Shakespeare has grown to be a part
                    of our <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>Anglo Saxon superstition<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">s</tei-hi>. The <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">T</tei-hi>hirty <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">N</tei-hi>ine articles are <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>now <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">F</tei-hi>orty. Intolerance
                    has come to exist in <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>this matter.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">You must believe in Shakespeare<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">'s</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    unapproachability,</tei-hi> or <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>quit the country. But what sort of a belief <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>is
                    this for an American, a man who is bound <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>to carry republican progress<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">-iveness</tei-hi> into <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">L</tei-hi>itera-<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>ture,
                    as well as into <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">L</tei-hi>ife?
                    Believe me, my <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>friends, that <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                        <tei-hi rend="bold" data-origname="hi">men</tei-hi> not very much inferior to</tei-hi> Shakespeare<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi> are this day
                    being born <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>on the banks of the Ohio. And the day will <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> come, when
                    you shall say who reads a book <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>by an Englishman <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">that is a modern?</tei-hi>
                    The great mistake <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>seems to be, that even with those Americans <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>who
                    look forward <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">to</tei-hi> the
                    coming of a <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>great <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    literary</tei-hi> genius among us, they somehow fancy he <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>will come in the
                    costume of Queen Elizabeth's <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>day,-- be a writer of dramas founded upon <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>old
                    English history, or the tales of Boccaccio. <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>Whereas, great geniuses are
                    part<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">s</tei-hi> of the times; <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>they
                    themselves are the times; and possess a <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>correspondent coloring. It is of a <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">piece</tei-hi> with <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">t</tei-hi>he Jews, who <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>while
                    their Shiloh was meekly walking in <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>their streets, were still praying for
                    his magnifi-<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>cent coming; looking for him in a chariot, who <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>was
                    already among them on an ass. Nor must we <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>forget, that, in his own
                    life-time, Shakespeare was</tei-p>
            </tei-div>

                </tei-div></tei-body></tei-text>

                    their Shiloh was meekly walking in <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>their streets, were still praying for
                    his magnifi-<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>cent coming; looking for him in a chariot, who <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>was
                    already among them on an ass. Nor must we <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>forget, that, in his own

                <tei-p data-origname="p">for the sake of any one man, whoever he <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>may be. This is too cheap a
                    purchase of contentment <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>for conscious mediocrity to make. Besides, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>this
                    absolute and unconditional adoration of <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>Shakespeare has grown to be a part

Intolerance
                    has come to exist in <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>this matter.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">You must believe in Shakespeare<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">'s</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    unapproachability,</tei-hi> or <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>quit the country. But what sort of a belief <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>is
                    this for an American, a man who is bound <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>to carry republican progress<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">-iveness</tei-hi> into <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">L</tei-hi>itera-<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>ture,
                    as well as into <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">L</tei-hi>ife?
                    Believe me, my <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>friends, that <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                        <tei-hi rend="bold" data-origname="hi">men</tei-hi> not very much inferior to</tei-hi> Shakespeare<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi> are this day
                    being born <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>on the banks of the Ohio. And the day will <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> come, when
                    you shall say who reads a book <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>by an Englishman <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">that is a modern?</tei-hi>
                    The great mistake <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>seems to be, that even with those Americans <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>who
                    look forward <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">to</tei-hi> the
                    coming of a <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>great <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    literary</tei-hi> genius among us, they somehow fancy he <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>will come in the
                    costume of Queen Elizabeth's <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>day,-- be a writer of dramas founded upon <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>old
                    English history, or the tales of Boccaccio. <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>Whereas, great geniuses are
                    part<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">s</tei-hi> of the times; <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>they
                    themselves are the times; and possess a <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>correspondent coloring. It is of a <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">piece</tei-hi> with <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">t</tei-hi>he Jews, who <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>while

It is of a <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">piece</tei-hi> with <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">t</tei-hi>he Jews, who <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>while
                    their Shiloh was meekly walking in <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>their streets, were still praying for
                    his magnifi-<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>cent coming; looking for him in a chariot, who <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>was
                    already among them on an ass. Nor must we <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>forget, that, in his own

                    has come to exist in <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>this matter.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">You must believe in Shakespeare<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">'s</tei-hi>

                    this for an American, a man who is bound <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>to carry republican progress<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">-iveness</tei-hi> into <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">L</tei-hi>itera-<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>ture,
                    as well as into <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">L</tei-hi>ife?
                    Believe me, my <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>friends, that <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                        <tei-hi rend="bold" data-origname="hi">men</tei-hi> not very much inferior to</tei-hi> Shakespeare<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi> are this day
                    being born <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>on the banks of the Ohio. And the day will <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> come, when
                    you shall say who reads a book <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>by an Englishman <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">that is a modern?</tei-hi>
                    The great mistake <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>seems to be, that even with those Americans <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>who
                    look forward <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">to</tei-hi> the
                    coming of a <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>great <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">

                    you shall say who reads a book <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>by an Englishman <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">that is a modern?</tei-hi>
                    The great mistake <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>seems to be, that even with those Americans <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>who
                    look forward <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">to</tei-hi> the
                    coming of a <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>great <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    literary</tei-hi> genius among us, they somehow fancy he <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>will come in the
                    costume of Queen Elizabeth's <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>day,-- be a writer of dramas founded upon <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>old
                    English history, or the tales of Boccaccio. <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>Whereas, great geniuses are

                    themselves are the times; and possess a <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>correspondent coloring. It is of a <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">piece</tei-hi> with <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">t</tei-hi>he Jews, who <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>while
                    their Shiloh was meekly walking in <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>their streets, were still praying for
                    his magnifi-<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>cent coming; looking for him in a chariot, who <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>was
                    already among them on an ass. Nor must we <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>forget, that, in his own

                    this for an American, a man who is bound <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>to carry republican progress<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">-iveness</tei-hi> into <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">L</tei-hi>itera-<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>ture,
                    as well as into <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">L</tei-hi>ife?
                    Believe me, my <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>friends, that <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                        <tei-hi rend="bold" data-origname="hi">men</tei-hi> not very much inferior to</tei-hi> Shakespeare<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi> are this day
                    being born <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>on the banks of the Ohio. And the day will <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> come, when
                    you shall say who reads a book <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>by an Englishman <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">that is a modern?</tei-hi>
                    The great mistake <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>seems to be, that even with those Americans <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>who
                    look forward <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">to</tei-hi> the
                    coming of a <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>great <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    literary</tei-hi> genius among us, they somehow fancy he <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>will come in the
                    costume of Queen Elizabeth's <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>day,-- be a writer of dramas founded upon <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>old
                    English history, or the tales of Boccaccio. <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>Whereas, great geniuses are
                    part<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">s</tei-hi> of the times; <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>they
                    themselves are the times; and possess a <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>correspondent coloring. It is of a <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">piece</tei-hi> with <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">t</tei-hi>he Jews, who <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>while
                    their Shiloh was meekly walking in <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>their streets, were still praying for
                    his magnifi-<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>cent coming; looking for him in a chariot, who <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>was
                    already among them on an ass. Nor must we <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>forget, that, in his own
                    life-time, Shakespeare was</tei-p>

Intolerance
                    has come to exist in <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>this matter.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">You must believe in Shakespeare<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">'s</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    unapproachability,</tei-hi> or <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>quit the country. But what sort of a belief <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>is
                    this for an American, a man who is bound <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>to carry republican progress<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">-iveness</tei-hi> into <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">L</tei-hi>itera-<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>ture,
                    as well as into <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">L</tei-hi>ife?
                    Believe me, my <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>friends, that <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                        <tei-hi rend="bold" data-origname="hi">men</tei-hi> not very much inferior to</tei-hi> Shakespeare<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi> are this day
                    being born <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>on the banks of the Ohio. And the day will <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> come, when
                    you shall say who reads a book <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>by an Englishman <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">that is a modern?</tei-hi>
                    The great mistake <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>seems to be, that even with those Americans <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>who
                    look forward <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">to</tei-hi> the
                    coming of a <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>great <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    literary</tei-hi> genius among us, they somehow fancy he <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>will come in the
                    costume of Queen Elizabeth's <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>day,-- be a writer of dramas founded upon <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>old
                    English history, or the tales of Boccaccio. <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>Whereas, great geniuses are
                    part<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">s</tei-hi> of the times; <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>they
                    themselves are the times; and possess a <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>correspondent coloring. It is of a <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">piece</tei-hi> with <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">t</tei-hi>he Jews, who <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>while
                    their Shiloh was meekly walking in <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>their streets, were still praying for
                    his magnifi-<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>cent coming; looking for him in a chariot, who <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>was
                    already among them on an ass. Nor must we <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>forget, that, in his own
                    life-time, Shakespeare was</tei-p>
            </tei-div>
