<tei-text data-xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="base" id="base" data-origname="text"><tei-body data-origname="body"><tei-div type="leaf" n="13" data-origname="div"><tei-pb facs="#f012" data-origname="pb" data-empty=""></tei-pb>

                <tei-p data-origname="p">for the sake of any one man, whoever he <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>may be. This is too cheap a
                    purchase of contentment <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>for conscious mediocrity to make. Besides, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>this
                    absolute and unconditional adoration of <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>Shakespeare has grown to be a part
                    of our <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>Anglo Saxon superstition<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">s</tei-hi>. The <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">T</tei-hi>hirty <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">N</tei-hi>ine articles are <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>now <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">F</tei-hi>orty. Intolerance
                    has come to exist in <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>this matter.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">You must believe in Shakespeare<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">'s</tei-hi>
               <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    unapproachability,</tei-hi> or <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>quit the country. But what sort of a belief <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>is
                    this for an American, a man who is bound <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>to carry republican progress<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">-iveness</tei-hi> into <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">L</tei-hi>itera-<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>ture,
                    as well as into <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">L</tei-hi>ife?
                    Believe me, my <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>friends, that <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                        <tei-hi rend="bold" data-origname="hi">men</tei-hi> not very much inferior to</tei-hi> Shakespeare<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">,</tei-hi> are this day
                    being born <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>on the banks of the Ohio. And the day will <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb> come, when
                    you shall say who reads a book <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>by an Englishman <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">that is a modern?</tei-hi>
                    The great mistake <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>seems to be, that even with those Americans <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>who
                    look forward <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">to</tei-hi> the
                    coming of a <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>great <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">
                    literary</tei-hi> genius among us, they somehow fancy he <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>will come in the
                    costume of Queen Elizabeth's <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>day,-- be a writer of dramas founded upon <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>old
                    English history, or the tales of Boccaccio. <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>Whereas, great geniuses are
                    part<tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">s</tei-hi> of the times; <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>they
                    themselves are the times; and possess a <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>correspondent coloring. It is of a <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">piece</tei-hi> with <tei-hi xmlns:tei="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" rend="bold" data-origname="hi">t</tei-hi>he Jews, who <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>while
                    their Shiloh was meekly walking in <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>their streets, were still praying for
                    his magnifi-<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>cent coming; looking for him in a chariot, who <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>was
                    already among them on an ass. Nor must we <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""></tei-lb>forget, that, in his own
                    life-time, Shakespeare was</tei-p>
            </tei-div>

            <tei-div type="leaf" n="14" data-origname="div">
                </tei-div></tei-body></tei-text>
